captions.text:
• From strawberry tigers to hairy nosed
marsupials

• We count down 15 of the rarest near-extinct
animals ever to walk the Earth

15 - Javan Rhino
• Also known as the "small-horned rhino"

• It used to be found all over the islands
of Java, Sumatra, parts of India and China

• Today though, it's critically endangered
- mainly due to poaching for its tiny horn

used in Chinese medicine
• The Southeast Asian wars also obliterated

most of its habitat, so now Javan Rhino numbers
barely exceed 40

14 - Amur Leopard
• These are found in the Primorye regions

of southeastern Russia
• This is the only leopard subspecies adapted

to a cold, snowy climate
• And according to a 2008 study, there are

only around 15 adults left in the wild
• The reason? Poaching, encroaching civilisations,

new roads, destruction of forests and climate
change

13 - Tarsiers
• These are found on the islands of Southeast

Asia, which includes Thailand, Cambodia, Indonesia
and The Philippines, but since they became

critically endangered, you'll only really
find them in Borneo

• The reason they're so rare and cherised
is that these Tarsiers are the only primates

alive who are 100% carnivorous
• They mostly go after insects, but they've

also been known to devour birds, bats, lizards
and snakes

12 - Northern Hairy-nosed Wombat
• This is one of three species of wombat

in existence
• It used to live all over New South Wales,

Victoria and Queensland, but in the last 100
years the population has been declining quite

harshly
• The reason? It has to fight for its food

against popular domesticated animals like
cow and sheep, so now just over 100 of these

wombats are left
11 - Western lowland gorilla

• These live in central Africa, and also
a wide area of the Congo jungles

• These gorillas show the intelligence of
a young child; they fashion tools to dig holes,

they can learn sign language up to 1,000 signs,
and we haven't yet discovered the full extent

of their mental capacity
• They endured deforestation, farming, grazing

and expanding human settlements, but it was
the Ebola virus in Africa that accounts for

90% of the species extinction, only leading
to just over 500 left in captivity

10 - Okapi
• This one looks like a strange zebra off-shoot,

but in reality it's a distant relative of
the giraffe, a VERY distant relative

• It was first discovered in ancient egypt,
the legend of an "african unicorn", and it's

considered a "living fossil" since it has
no close living relatives, only those species

long, long dead
• Currently there are between 10 and 20,000

thousand Okapi alive today
9 - Iberian Lynx

• This is a carnivorous mammal native to
the Iberian Peninsula, Southern Europe

• It's numbers only total around 100 with
the primary cause poaching of its main prey,

the European rabbit, and the Lynx is physically
unable to alter its diet

• Numbers have also been reduced from habitat
loss, car accidents, feral dog hunting and

certain types of illness
8 - Mountain Pygmy Possum

• This is a small, mouse-sized marsupial
found in the dense apline rock screes and

boulder fields of Australia
• It mostly feeds on fruits, nuts and seeds

• And the reason it's so rare? Ski resorts
were built on its habitats, that combined

with climate change, death by feral cats and
foxes and decline of the Bogong moth also

contributed to the decline to less than 100
total

7 - Sao Tome Shrew
• These little guys are found only on Sao

Tome Island, a shield volcano off the Atlantic
Ocean

• They were first disovered in 1886, and
they're endangered due to habitat loss, deforestation

and a restricted range
• Information on the shrews is limited and

conservation is difficult because they're
so well cut off from the world, leading people

to believe they're closer to extinction than
previously thought

6 - Tamaraw (the Dwarf Water Buffalo)
• This is a small hoofed animal that used

to roam the island of Mindora in the Philippines,
but due to habitat loss from farming, cattle

ranching and the expansion of urban areas,
they're numbers now only total about 300

• Currently you can only find them in the
Mount Iglit-Baco National Park, where they're

protected from poaching and disease
5 - Philippine crocodile

• Only one of two species of crocodile also
found in the Philippines, it became critically

endangered in 2008 due to exploitation and
unsustainable fishing methods, which includes

dynamite fishing, in which water is blown
up to kill schools of animals for easy collection

• As of today, there exists only about 250
specimens of this crocodile alive, and there

are laws prohibiting the slaughtering of crocodile
in that country

4 - Red Wolf
• This is a cousin of the Gray Wolf, and

for a while during the 1980s it was believed
the red wolf HAD gone extinct

• But some turned up in captivity, around
20, and thanks to conservation that number

rose to over 200 with 100 living in the wild,
though the environmental factors that caused

to be nearly extinct still exist today - that
their hunting grounds have become severely

depleted
3 - Hispid Hare

• A type of rabbit from the southern foothills
of the Himalayan mountains

• It lives in tall grass but since mankind
totalled its habitat and hunted a vast majority

of them, they're on the verge of extinction,
just over 100 left in the wild

• It's unlikely the species will survive
moving forward

2 - Golden Tabby Tiger
• This one can ONLY be found in captivity,

and its odd coat has had some to title it
the "strawberry tiger"

• Its species has been around since the
early 1900s, and strangely enough they only

appeared in areas with a heavy concentration
of clay in the soil

• As of today, less than 30 of these tigers
are known to exist

1 - The Pinta Island Tortoise
• This species is so rare that only 1 individual

was found
• It's one of the famous giant Galapagos

tortoises, and sadly they were hunted remorselessly
over the years for meat

• 
In the 1970s, an old male tortoise was found,
believed to be the last of his kind, and they

called him lonesome george
• A huge number of attempts to get him to

reproduce failed, and in 2012 he died
• Though in that same year, 17 first gen

hybrids were discovered, bringing hope to
that forever gone species

comments.text:
Survival of the fittest has been pretty good way of dealing with moral 
issues regarding what humans do on this planet. 
"Survival of the fittest"  says the hunter and shoots White rhino, so that 
he can saw his horn off and get money. 
"Survival of the fittest" says a poacher who sells tiger skins to a private 
collector.
"Survival of the fittest! says farmer and destroys entire species of 
Tasmanian tiger, so that he does´t loose few sheep to it.
I have problems seeing how destroying these species in any way, helps us 
survive. We only hunt when we need food or when we are in danger, just like 
animals do/have done. That is survival of the fittest. 
Every living creature has a purpose, a connection to it's environment. The 
mass extinctions happened fast and were not avoidable because they were 
cataclysmic events. So yes, every species can become extinct at some point. 
But humans are the only other species that can cause extinction of another 
species on such scale. it kind of speaks for itself, that we don´t live in 
connection with our environment. Nature balances things out. When wolves 
multiply by a lot, eventually they starve, because there is not enough food 
for all.. and the balance prevails. Same for deer. Too much deer, wolves 
thrive and balance the amount of deer. WE DON'T BALANCE SHIT. 
People here say, that that is evolution, a natural order of things, but 
perhaps we should stop interfering with human evolution too and let all 
weak, sick, disabled and deformed also die? I mean because.. survival of 
the fittest?
Does't work this way.﻿
comments.author: MagMaybe

comments.text: 1:01 It is looking into your soul﻿
comments.author: Rob Bibler

comments.text:
Alot of the "anti-animal" arguments I'm reading in these comments are 
justified by pretty much the same shit. "We do that because we can and we 
are all that matters."

Hmm... A bear CAN come into your home and eat you and your children. But it 
doesn't. On average someone who swims in the ocean at least once a year 
will be within 15 feet of a shark large enough to mutilate them. But it 
doesn't. Why? Because they don't need to. They can find food and that's all 
they need. Human beings don't need a majority of the bullshit they acquire. 
Yet they do. Because they can. And the only thing that matters is them. 
Don't you think the bear cares more about itself than you?


The thing that is so fucked up about the extinction of thousands of species 
in the last 600 years is that it didn't need to happen. We would have 
survived and still thrived without the eradication of countless animals. 
Some of which are so fascinating and so rare that they live on only in 
myth... when we could have seen and studied them in real life if we didn't 
destroy their habitat and remorselessly hunt them down. Unlike some people, 
I can see all that nature has given us, and I think that by only paying it 
back with destruction is the same as biting the hand that feeds you. It's 
low. It's more than low. Bite it enough and that hand will stop feeding you.


Honestly I do sometimes wish a pack of rouge bears would come and eat 
entire towns so people could know what it feels like to be hunted down to 
the last man. But, of course, we wouldn't learn a lesson there. We'd just 
kill off all the bears for doing a minute scale version of what we've done 
for millennia.﻿

even if we do, we only look at the simplest solution... to eradicate them.

comments.text:
You forgot the most endangered species on earth: the Yangtze giant 
softshell turtle, the largest freshwater turtle in the world. Due to 
habitat loss, only four of its kind are left: a very old male and female 
pair in a zoo in China and two rarely sighted males in separate lakes in 
Vietnam. Multiple attempts have been made to get the zoo pair to breed, but 
all I have been unsuccessful so far (the male is 100 and the female is 80). 
Biologists fear that soon the turtles will grow too old to breed and the 
species will disappear forever. In 2014, it was found that the male may be 
infertile. Sad.﻿

comments.text:
"Strawberry Tigers" are NOT an actual a species of tiger it is a color 
morph bred in captivity out of Bengal tigers sometimes cross bred with 
Siberian as many captive tigers are cross breeds. And is not rare or going 
extinct because it was not found in the wild what so ever it was a human 
created coloration by selective breeding programs mostly for private 
collectors and some dubious zoos.. The same can be said for the nearly all 
white variants and 'golden' tigers among many other color morphs. Shave it 
down and there is nothing special about the tiger other then it's colors, 
nothing genetically or physically distinct about it. A variance in color 
does not equal that of a new species, the defining traits of a unique 
species is in it's genetic and physiological makeup. ﻿

comments.text:
The "Golden Tabby Tiger" is not its own species, it's a color mutation, 
much like a white tiger. If they become extinct... well, good. The same 
goes for white tigers and many other mutations in other species, and even 
to an extent, specific breeds of cats and dogs.

If you're not aware, these pretty-looking color mutations only happen 
through selective breeding, and through selective breeding, bad things can 
happen. Sometimes a mutation is SO rare that it has only happened in 
animals that are siblings or close family to each other, so a brother and 
sister may be paired to mate, or mother and son, etc. Such disgusting 
inbreeding makes the mutation more likely to happen again, but it may also 
create an animal that is severely deformed or defected at birth, which may 
give it a miserable life.

That is why people do not inbreed, aside from the morals that mark it as 
wrong. It thins out the gene pool, it makes you less diverse, weaker. A 
diverse gene pool is a healthy gene pool. Unfortunately, this is also how 
many purebred animals are birthed, such as chihuahuas, rottweilers, 
scottish fold cats and persians alike,﻿

comments.text:
Its not about humans being superior to other animals or other animals being 
superior to humans... Cant there be a little give and take on each end? We 
should have more respect for the earth and animals and try to preserve as 
much of the earth as we can because it once was a beautiful place. Some 
people love nature, some people love infrastructure and technological 
advancement. We should have had a plan drawn up a long time ago to leave as 
much of the earth as natural as possible while also creating infrastructure 
because humans have amazing minds and we should put it to use, but its too 
late for that now. We should be focused now on working with areas we've 
already destroyed and stop going any further because its already gone too 
far. Not to say humans are wrong for advancing, we didn't know it would 
come to this, but we should start to realize that if we keep doing this 
there will literally be no more natural earth left, which is not fair to 
some people who love the beauty of nature, because this is everyones earth. 
We can advance where we already exist.﻿

I know most people hate animals living in captivity, but I am sometimes 
glad it exists. The animals are usually well cared for, respected, and live 
out their lives free of poaching. When I say captivity I mean.. huge open 
pen areas resembling wilderness. Not cages.
I guess I ask you: would you rather have the animals go extinct or have 
(some of) them preserved in captivity?
And no, leaving the animals alone sounds good on paper but humans will 
always be humans. Poachers will always be a thing and their environments 
are being ruined via climate change and deforestation/etc.﻿

comments.text:
+Dan A A large portion of all conflicts are resources and control. Politics 
play a part of it but it's not the major player in it.

Please don't tell me that you believe what you're saying about companies. 
Who do you think is in control of the big corporations? There's a few 
corporations in the world who control the smaller ones. Also that is not 
the point I was trying to make. I was talking about the whole system of 
"get up, go work, go home, sleep, repeat". That's the big portion of ours 
lives in a nut shell. Well... The big majority of it anyway.

What you tried to say about the hormones is entirely untrue. It's actually 
the opposite. After cows started to get injected with hormones - their 
health got worse and the meat can cause countless health problems to those 
who eat them longterm, but the cows produced a lot more milk so that's good 
for business. It doesn't make them healthier in any way, shape or form, or 
you... You really think that the ones who make those products think about 
the quality of their products? That is really depressing... I'm sorry to 
break it to you, but there's only one thing people in that industry cares 
about and you probably know what that is. If pushing toxic but cheaper 
products would be legal - they would do it. They don't give a shit about 
you or anyone else who eats that meat. You should watch Documentary "Food 
Inc." it covers most of what I'm trying to say here and more.

How can you be so selfish? It's really hard for me to comprehend such 
scumbaggery... No one will stop you forcibly, but if it was made legal, I 
would do more than stop you from hunting other animals.

That is the entire point. Money is what stops humanity from being something 
more than mindless, fucking assholes like you. But I don't have time to get 
into that discussion right now.

You need to wake up and smell the coffee, because I cringe at your utter 
materialism and selfishness. I really don't have anything else to say to 
you, because I get worked up because of your ignorance.

comments.text:
+Dan A oh wow. Where do I even begin here.

We won't colonize other planets any time soon. We won't deplete entirely 
Earth's resources, because we will destroy each other before we can do 
that. Look at the world right now. Worldwide conflicts brewing every day. 
We are in a brink of world war 3 and you think that we will venture into 
space some time tomorrow? Don't. Just don't.

It's sad that you think that without destroying your own planet you can 
only wear "leave pajamas" and live in "mud huts". Your thinking is so 
simplistic and one directional as it possibly can be. If instead of making 
products to control you - we made products to help our needs and the 
environment, everything would be infinitely times better. But it won't - 
because of people like you, who stay the way it is right now. We are 
evolving, but to what direction? People with higher power don't care about 
any of us or the world they live in. All they care about is how to control 
you and me. You are saying things that they want you to say. Like we've got 
the right to exploit our planet's resources and lives of other sentient 
beings - humans or nonhumans. Electricity can easily be made with magnet 
generators. Everything has an alternative for the better of everyone, but 
because those things won't make a profit like the ones right now - no one 
will do it. That is the point here.

In my opinion - we live in the dark ages. Just with a better technology. If 
you think that technology alone shows how we are not in the dark - I feel 
very sorry for you. Our ways of doing things have changed, but the purpose 
stayed the same and in most cases got even worse. For example - in "the 
dark ages" as you call it, our ancestors hunted to survive and to eat 
another day, but in today's society - humans breed animals, inject them 
with hormones that cause those animals enormous pain and suffering, 
separate mothers from their cubs just so they wouldn't drink all the milk 
from their mother that was meant for them. Not only that, but keep them in 
machines so their leg muscles couldn't form to produce more tender meat, 
then slaughter them and keep doing it for the biggest profit. If this is 
the direction we are evolving to, I want to part of it. No other animal in 
this world will ever reach the level of cruelty of ours.

Last time I checked, Benq, MSI and other companies don't cut any trees and 
it's not made of animal parts - so I doubt any animals had to be killed in 
the process of making my computer. More so, how do you know what methods 
are used to make electricity in my city? There's different ways to run 
different generators to generate energy. It brings me back to alternate 
methods. Everything you state in your paragraphs can be made without 
harming environment, animals and humans. You just have to do some research 
about them. No one uses those, because the ones that they use now brings 
more profit. Everything around you is being run by greed of other people. 
People that don't want you to be free. Your whole life is about serving 
someone "more important" than you, but the fact is - no one is more 
important. Every person or living being deserves his way of freedom.

So the questions I want to ask is - Why can't we adapt our technology for 
the better of everyone on the planet? Not just the people who are in charge 
or just people, but everything? Animals, plants and so on. We are so 
advanced that we see ourselves better than animals, which by your opinion 
doesn't care about anything else but themselves. So if we are more advanced 
and not like other animals - why focus solely on ourselves and see other 
beings suffer just so you could have a more comfortable life? Didn't we 
reach a point now that we are beyond only survival? Does the selfish life 
of being On Top of The Food Chain fulfill you? Surely you say that Earth's 
resources are so vast and plentiful, so why not use it for something else 
more than ourselves?

comments.text:
I'm just wondering sometimes why is it considered something negative when a 
species goes extinct? I mean sure I can understand that in some extreme 
cases like bees for example it would greatly affect the ecosystem and cause 
the extinction of other animals or plants because of that but in general 
why should I care if say dolphins or pandas go extinct? What exactly is 
their significance aside from being cute? This is the way nature has been 
working for billions of years and approximately more than 99% of all 
species that have ever roamed this planet have gone extinct. I think most 
animal lovers seem to forget that we humans are a part of nature so if a 
species directly or indirectly goes extinct because of us it's just a part 
of natural selection, isn't it? How is that a bad thing?﻿

at least why do some (including me) care? Because some of us are 
compassionate beings and we would hate to see another creature die and be 
completely wiped out of existence even if they "are not vital to our own 
survival" thats why. Because some of us DO think and see the value in each 
living being even if its not a contributory value. Although IMO every 
living thing does even if it cant be explained or scientifically proven. To 
put it simple - We cant co-exist because we simply dont want to co-exist.

Think about it this way: the ecosystem is a tower built with children's 
building blocks. Each species is one block, if one gets pulled out more 
fall down. So if gazelles were wiped out, lions and cheetahs would suffer a 
shake, they would need new prey. So they need to adapt, or go extinct with 
the gazelle. And if lions and cheetahs went extinct then other animals 
would skyrocket in population. So if one species goes extinct, the entire 
ecosystem would suffer.

comments.text:
I know I have posted this on comments, but feel free to give you opinions 
on this. And please do correct me if I'm mathematically or scientifically 
incorrect.

Okay, so most of you pretty much hate the man race for doing such things to 
animals. Some people might even go as far as to hope for the extinction of 
our own race. But I did some research and some math, and if there are 
100,000,000 different species on earth, and the extinction rate is 
0.01%/year, at least 10,000 species will go instinct each year. But keep in 
mind that scientifically, between 1.4 and 1.8 million species has been 
discovered. Now keep I'm mind that over 95% percent of the ocean is 
undiscovered, and the ocean makes up 70% of the earth. 80% of that 100% of 
species are still undiscovered. The fact that we still have not grasped 
even the most simplistic way of discovering half of those 80% of species, 
or half of that 95% of oceanic floor should make you think. The 1.4-1.8 
million we have scientifically found, vs the 7.3-6.9 million species still 
yet to be discovered, making a total estimate of 8.7 million species in 
total, or maybe more since 70% or more of our earth is either undiscovered 
or unexplored. With this being said, estimating that the lowest would be 
around 100 million different species is true, then there are about 2 
million species discovered/yet to be explored more in depth. . The the rate 
would be about 200 - 2,000 extinctions each year. This is accounting for 
the loss of our biodiversity, but there are too many variables to keep 
track of. As a pose to natural extinction rate which would be 
1,000-10,000'less that it is now. Though I hate to imagine how much 
biodiversity we are losing while still maintaing the ecosystem services 
that humanity depends upon. I wouldn't go as fat to hope we as a species 
die, for there are a few out there who at least try to something instead of 
sitting watching this video and complain how 'humans are single handedly 
destroying endangered animals'. The Convention on Biological Diversity 
(CBD) is actually trying to save them by starting the Biodiversity Action 
Plan (BAP) by identifying these animals and saving them. Instead of sitting 
here, again, complaining. ﻿

I'm looking at all of these comments below saying that animals are at the 
same level as humans. They are kind of right and kind of wrong.

As humans, we do what any other animal does-to survive and thrive.We build 
communities to live and socialise in. You could say that we are the 
"dominant" species on the planet, like dinosaurs were millions of years 
ago, and due to this, we a
are proud.

We are proud of what we have achieved.We are proud of how far we have come. 
We have increased our intelligence so that we can get a better life for 
ourselves. To animals, this has been done to a limited state.

We should be proud of where we all live. We should be proud that we can 
view beautiful phenomena that occurs on our planet-phenomena that occurs 
no-where else. However we are wrecking this due to all of the pollution 
that we are causing.

We should also be proud about the fact that we live alongside such 
beautiful flora and fauna. If there was no poaching, then the earth would 
work the same for us. Elephants are now growing without tusks to stop 
people poaching them. We have removed some beauty from this plant. While we 
are not responsible for all the extinctions, we are the culprits for most 
of them.

Overall. We need to be proud of this planet. We need to be proud of all the 
breathtaking views, all of the wonderful phenomena, and all of the 
beautiful plants and animals.

But it is obvious that we are not proud of them,because,if you were proud 
of something,wouldn't you take care of it?﻿

For all those in the comments saying that all humans suck and go animals 
and stuff, us killing helps them as well. Maybe not to the extinct on some 
but hunting keeps population in check. And not really just for that 
species. We do take it over board though. I will admit that.
However, for those saying the world would be better off of humans died. 
That is false. Humanity is a large supporter of life. If our race dies out 
then countless others will soon fall behind. Which leads to others. And a 
huge chain reaction. Ecosystems suffer as well. The reason why is because, 
as I explained before, we keep populations in check. We are one of the main 
predators for some animals. If we die then they will reach their carrying 
capacities and eventually hurt themselves. Then they will die and leave 
other animals without food and others will get out of control to. 
Plant life comes into affect when nothing is there to eat or maintain it. 
It becomes overgrown and such, causing other plants not to get sunlight. ﻿

Danger Dolan! You have provided me with false information...

Strawberry tigers are not rare due to hunting and they are not a different 
species of tiger, the colour is caused by a recessive gene and they have 
been bred in captivity, a phenomenon that many times occurs by accident! 
Please do research... Yes strawberry tigers were hunted because of their 
coats more so than other tigers, however they are not a different species 
and therefore cannot go extinct, and were generally extremely rare to begin 
with.﻿

comments.text:
Tarsier is still not extinct in the Philippines.

Source: Wikipedia

A sanctuary near the town of Corella, on the Philippine island of Bohol, is 
having some success restoring tarsier populations. The Philippines Tarsier 
Foundation (PTFI) has developed a large, semiwild enclosure known as the 
Tarsier Research and Development Center. Carlito Pizarras, also known as 
the "Tarsier man", founded this sanctuary where visitors can watch tarsiers 
up close in the wild (naturally without touching them)﻿

comments.text:
Why do people kill those rare animals? Well those people who, most of the 
time, live under a dollar a day, don't go by your wealthy logic. They are 
in survival mode. Food is food and money is food. 

The world is messed up, but for only humans. At the end of the day, we, 
beings of this planet, have to respond to Mother Nature in some way. Years 
ago you would of told me something like this and I would of called you 
crazy. The truth of the matter is; the planet is either going to die by an 
indeterminate natural cause or is going to be just fine long after the 
humans, us, the plague is gone.

Now, you may not realize it but, there is something ugly coming out for us. 
If the theory of evolution is true and follow it's evolutionary course, 
soon enough we are going to be the preys of some newborn predator or 
predators (and they don't have to be huge, they can be as little as 
insects). And when that happens, no insect repellant will be strong enough, 
because we may think the world isn't changing but it is creating its own 
defense mechanism. 

Us removing all those animals is our own doomed signature. We need those 
species to populate. Without the faun and the Flore something nasty is 
going to get to us.﻿

The lynx is beautiful too. I was actually able to see a white tiger in 
person one time, and it wasn't at a zoo! This traveling group came to my 
town once and they had a bunch of animals with them that you can't find in 
the wilds of America. They had this booth where you could get a family 
photo with a Bengal tiger cub, and yes its mom was there too. There was 
this line going to the back of the area and people were like all excited to 
go back there, so we got in line. When we made in the special area, the he 
was; a gorgeous male white tiger. Unfortunately, he was taking a nap so we 
didn't get to see him do anything, but it was still just enough to be able 
to see such a magnificent creature in person.

comments.text:
We should just try to breed these animals into their related populations. 
For example, nearly all big cats can interbreed and produce fertile 
offspring. Same as cattle varieties. Breed them and create hybrids with 
more robust species. We don't need to preserve the individual species in 
order to keep the animals alive. Particularly because the more we try to 
conserve them, the more they end up inbreeding and gaining deformities.

That's what they did with the tortoise, and it can be done with other 
endangered species as well.﻿

aggree that cloning is one of the better safeguards that we currently
have. but what i'm saying is this, before we start suggesting cloning
to others as a solution, we should take every other possible measures
to try and avoid using it in the first place and instead encourage
them to take actions today, and it is these actions that they take
today that will change what happens in the future. as so many others
have said, it is not too late to start acting right now. for example,
we can start by finding ways to prevent the ongoing destruction of
these animals' habitats.
comments.author: Nathan Gareth

comments.text:
+Nathan Gareth True. My idea was actually to help the current animal 
species regrow. Recreating an extinct species is irresponsible, as there's 
no habitat for them. I don't want to use cloning as a way to simply cut out 
the regrets and consequences of our actions. The cloning system is 
imperfect, and I've learned a lot through this thread about how it works 
and what the consequences are.
However, I actually wanted to use the cloning technology as another form of 
a safeguard against animals going extinct. I feel like I'm rehashing my 
idea, but I want to make sure that the core message still gets across.
comments.author: Sarah S.

comments.text:
+Sarah S. 
Yes, he did tell us to rule over the earth and all animals, but he also 
told us to remember the sabbath day and to keep it holy, but then, in the 
new testament, jesus comes along and tells us something different. The 
bible is very contradictory and im sure that somewhere further in the 
bible, he is regretting that decision.
And i respect your point, but we should not go around promoting cloning, or 
else people will start saying " oh it's nothing if this animal goes extinct 
today, we'll just collect it's dna and clone it later on." (this cloned 
animal will most likely not be returned to the wild). Cloning should really 
be our plan Z. Right now we should be taking actions to prevent these 
animals from going extint in the first place. Prevention is better than 
cure.

comments.text:
I hope he knows the so-called "strawberry tiger" is not a species of tiger 
at all, but a coat mutation caused by a recessive gene. Like the white 
tigers.

I know Wikipedia isn't the best source for great information, but it has 
the most hits, its the top of the page, and if you were to read the first 
three sentences of the article, it'd actually say this: "A golden tiger, 
golden tabby tiger or strawberry tiger is a tiger with a color variation 
caused by a recessive gene. The coloration is a result of captive breeding 
and does not occur in the wild. Like the white tiger, it is a colour form 
and not a separate species."

Just like white tigers, it's caused by captive breeding and if this coat 
were to appear in the wild, the tiger would be unlikely to live.﻿

comments.text:
+ultimateplayer52 Human ignorance. Do you understand anything about 
ecology? Even our domesticated animals that we survive and even thrive off 
of are being poisoned and subsequently poisoning this world. Pollution, 
soil erosion, and a dramatic waste of FOOD come from us throwing a natural 
environment out of balance. Even in the case of making a population 
explode. (ie cattle)

Everything effects everything on this earth. We don't even understand the 
full extent of ecology but we know that when we abuse and overuse the land 
we can no longer live off it. That's a concept so simple a 5th grader could 
understand. That is what we are doing to the world. 

If we do not stop we will see major food and resource shortages within our 
lifetimes. And part of the reason is because we are destroying the 
environment and the creatures that naturally coexist with other creatures. 
That other creatures, ones we live off of, use to live. Human beings can 
have a symbiotic relationship with earth if we choose. But as has been said 
we choose not to due to greed. Because of this we will not only destroy 
large amounts of the beauty in this earth, but also ourselves. We will 
become the extinct species in the end because of this "the only thing that 
is important is me" mentality.


Don't worry though. We're not quite there yet. There will be decades and 
possibly centuries of starvation, warfare, and suffering before we finally 
die out.

comments.text:
Ever heard of the snow leopard it lives in mountains in snow and cold the 
Amur leopard is not the only leopard that lives in cold regions. Also 
should the strawberry tiger really be on this list it is a color mutation 
not a new subspecies. It serves no purpose in the wild and like white 
tigers, white lions, king cheetahs, stripeless tigers, and snow tigers they 
are horrible inbred and are only around for the entertainment of humans. If 
you ever looked up the statistics on these inbred animals you would be 
horrified just do a search for on the realities of white tigers most are 
born horribly deformed the only way to get these tigers or lions is by 
breeding babies back to their parents or breeding siblings. Deformed babies 
are put down as are normal colored siblings as they suffer the same defects 
as their odd colored siblings all white tigers are born cross eyed even if 
they look normal they will still have defects you can't see. The golden or 
strawberry tiger is the same way and the whole clay thing is not proven 
they have only cropped up once in the wild and were  very isolated making 
inbreeding likely. They crop up in captivity in litters who's parents carry 
the stripless and white tiger gene. If you breed two golden tigers you can 
get a mix of normal colored cubs, white cubs (probably stripless or very 
little stripping), and  golden tiger cubs like all inbred color mutation 
neonate mortality and deformities are likely. Whats more is that these 
tigers are not even pure bred they are a mix of Siberian and Bengal tigers 
making them useless for conservation if the severe deformities and 
inbreeding didn't already exclude them.﻿

comments.text:
please: the golden (and white) tigers are *not* separate tiger species.
You mention they are only bred in captivity, what most people fail to grasp 
is this as a result of often incest, as the gene that passes this 
appearance on is recessive and requires both parents to possess it. The 
breeding often results in gross genetic problems, physical, mental and 
health problems ongoing for their entire lives, as a money-pulling 
attractions. (look up Kenny the White Tiger)

Especially the case with white tiger breeders, those cubs born that fail to 
have the variant, are often killed. These are two 'species' of cat that 
need to be a thing of the past, with us moving forwards to the preservation 
and support of a healthy tiger population, in both zoos and the wild.﻿

comments.text:
The strawberry tiger facts are wrong and are a product of severe INBREEDING 
just like white tigers. Only the strawberry tabby tiger is made from a 
white tiger bred with a regular orange tiger. It's not an "endangered 
species" just like a lot of people are made to believe with the white tiger.

From wikipedia: "India has records of wild golden tigers which date back as 
far as the early 1900s. There have been *suggestions* that the tendency for 
this coloration gradually developed in a small group of tigers living in an 
area of heavy clay concentration. The unusual colour would provide these 
tigers with extra camouflage. The theory remains unproven; however, 
inbreeding of a small isolated group of tigers could cause the recessive 
golden tiger gene to emerge if at least one of those tigers carried the 
recessive gene for the golden colour and bred with its own offspring."

That's all the clay theory is, is speculation. The truth is inbreeding.﻿

comments.author: Adriel Puello

comments.text:
+Adriel Puello

Did you seriously just...

The stupidity in this post.

I'm going to leave this here:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dating_methodologies_in_archaeology

" Supposedly evolution takes millions of years to take place. Making it 
impossible for anything to evolve, because that animal/person would die 
before 1 million years."

Dear god, I am facedesking so hard right now. It's not one single 
individual animal that evolves, it's hundreds in a line of animals. 

Let me give you this as an example.

This is called natural selection:
There are two sets of bugs. One has a biological immunity to a certain type 
of poison that a farmer sprays, the other doesn't, this one is the control 
group. The farmer sprays the poison, and the control group dies, and the 
other goes on to mate with a group of females that weren't exposed to the 
poison. The immunity trait then gets passe don the children of that bug, 
and  a generation of poison immune bugs have just been made.

The idea of Natural Selection is often shortened to survival of the 
fittest. But Natural Selection actually states that those better adapted to 
the environment will produce more offspring that will live, thus producing 
more animals with the adaptations that allow them to survive. Whereas those 
without the adaptations will die off because they can not produce as much 
offspring.

Now extrapolate this over millions of years, and you get the basis of 
Evolution.

Evolution doesn't say we came from chimps, it says that chimps and Humans 
share a common ancestor. A place in our history where we split and became 
the original template for Humanity. However, we have yet to find that 
missing link, the Father, or possibly even, Mother of Humanity. But that 
doesn't mean it doesn't exist. As conditions for fossilization often don't 
exist. Or the fossil possibly didn't even survive up to this point.
comments.author: KaBar41

comments.text:

comments.author: Adriel Puello

comments.text:
Evolution is a theory, yes.
Evolution has some holes in it, yes.
We do NOT come from monkeys! The theory suggests that Humans, apes, monkeys 
and other primates share the same ancestor, and this is backed up through 
genetic research.
A lizard did not "turn into a Tyrannosaurus Rex". Evolution merely suggests 
that reptiles developed earlier, and housed similar characteristics to 
them. Dinosaurs in general are more attributed to birds based on the 
genetic structure we've gathered, as well as bone structure, and the 
discovery that some dinosaur species house evidence of feathers and 
feather-like appendages.
Another leaning towards the theory of Evolution is the eerily striking 
similarities between entirely species of animals when studying early formed 
foetuses. I highly doubt a deity would go to the trouble to make an early 
Human embryo look similar to one of a fish, right down to the evidence of a 
tail and gills!
Don't laugh off Evolution as a fanciful delusion made up by Athiests. 
Darwin was a devout Christian who was trying to figure out how the world 
worked. And this isn't addressing the theory that he plagiarised the 
information from other Naturalists and his remark on how Aboriginals 
"exhibit Human-like behaviour".
I probably got some information wrong, but I'm merely using memory based on 
information I've gathered over the years. Evolution just makes the most 
sense to me. Until some other method is discovered and scientifically 
proven my money on Evolution.

The reason the Iberian lynx is endangered is because a scientist tried to 
make a rabbit repellant but accidentally made a disease that nearly wiped 
the lynxes food source (rabbits) out. The lynx is now protected and a 
project to reintroduce healthy rabbits to Spain is going on. I'm sick of 
people saying that human beings should not care about nature (because 
they're belief should be everyone else's ) and I'm sick people saying 
humans are evil (we make mistakes get over it) but most of all I'm sick of 
beauty dying. Not beauty dying at the hands of humans, just beauty dying 
full stop. So if anyone else knows about any projects to help the animals 
on this list tell me publicly so the top comments will be helpful to any 
one who's not bothered to do any research and the top comments might 
actually be worth reading. To me it's not about the mistakes in the past. 
It's about what we're doing now to fix them. ﻿

comments.text:
You. . .you do know the poor or poverty stricken also contribute to the 
decimation of a species?
Gorillas and Tigers are hunted for their meat by starving families, while 
desperate farmers clear habitats, which cuts off migration routes and 
causes conflicts with native species due to farmers protecting their crops 
or their animals. Also cheap labour is hired to mine for resources in 
national parks, and some of those people also poach for food or the black 
market. Poorer people also tend to be less educated, and tend to follow 
superstitions that can condemn entire species based on false information, 
ignorance, or fear.
Civil wars can also cause extinction from collateral damage, whether it be 
from active hunting, the spread of disease or contamination of the 
surrounding habitat.
It's not just a wealthy white man hunting for sport that causes extinction. 
Please, please realise that there's no black and white involving 
extinction. The world is much more complicated than "grr Humans bad, 
animals good!"

comments.author: Killmekos2

comments.text:
A little correction: Strawberry Tabby Tigers/Golden Tigers are not rare or 
near-extinct. They're not a species, but a color morph of the bengal tiger. 
And all thirty of them are related, since their color can only be achieved 
by inbreeding, seeing how the last Golden Tiger in the wild was seen in 
1930. They're just like white tigers, who are in the same boat, and just as 
inbred.

The reason why they're rarely seen in the wild, is because due to their 
coat coloring, they have problems hiding, and so can get spotted by prey 
and can't find any food. Most of them get abandoned by their mothers, 
though,

While tigers themselves are critiically endangered and should be met with 
conservation effort, Golden Tabbies, along with white ones, are ONLY bred 
for profit, since they don't meet any conservation effort. I love your 
videos, but that really needed correction, because the practice of 
inbreeding for profit is pretty cruel, and the species would be a lot 
better off if normal tigers were bred and returned to the wild.﻿

comments.text:
Fact: Humans are the ONLY species that gives a single fuck about a lesser 
animal that is about to go extinct.  Do you think the wolves cared when the 
sabertoothed cats disappeared from the Earth?  Do you think the horses in 
Europe cared when their big brother the Hagerman's Horse went extinct in 
America?  Nope, the only thing that makes us an affront and mistake of 
nature is that we give too many fucks.  If we ever wipe ourselves out for 
the sake of stupid, selfish ideals like I bet we will, I hope our 
successors never have this problem.  I'd rather live in a cold, bleak,

comments.text:
These videos always turn into "demonize all mankind" commentary. It's not 
like the vast majority of people today try to pollute, or destroy species 
and habitats, or disrupt ecosystems. It's pretty much what we were born 
into. Our modern lifestyle is not currently sustainable without these 
consequences. It's likely to get worse before it gets better with the 
exploding human population in undeveloped countries and their eventual 
spike in need for resources as more people afford to live a non-poverty 
stricken lifestyle. Heads up, if you're able to read this on your fancy 
pants computer with electricity, you're probably part of these problems in 
some way. Did you do it on purpose? I doubt it. At least we go to the 
effort of lessening our impact as time goes on, and make conservation 
efforts. I feel sorry for animals like poor Lonesome George, especially 
being a big tortoise with absolutely no chance to escape or defend itself 
from a poacher. However, we should not all be looked upon as scum for the 
actions of some poachers.﻿

rivers is natural, detonating a nuclear bomb is natural, I don't know,

comments.author: 0vilge0

comments.text:
Well, generally spoken, you're right. However, in some cases, a species is 
pivotal for a certain environment. For example, bee populations have been 
in a permanent decline over the course of the past few years due to 
insecticides, paracides and other chemicals. If they were to die out, this 
would cause a vast number of trees and bushes to go extinct as well. Well, 
according to your reasoning, that's not all that bad. If they're gone, 
they're gone, and nobody should worry, right? Some of those trees affected 
the most by a potential extinction of bees are apple and other cultivated 
fruit trees, and a vast number of other plants important to us humans for 
one or another reason. So, well, maybe not giving a fuck's not always the 
best idea.

comments.text:
The golden tabby tiger is the result of a genetic mutation caused by 
captive breeding.  It does not, and never has, occurred in the wild.  It is 
not truly an endangered species, because it is not a separate species at 
all.  It is just a different color form of Panthera tigris tigris (bengal 
tiger), usually caused by orange and white tiger varieties interbreeding.  
Really shouldn't be on this list.﻿

Actually, not knowing about a species doesn't protect it. If we don't know 
it's there then we'll damage its environment and contaminate its food 
supply. A frog species in the Snowy Mountains of Australia were almost 
completely eradicated until we discovered it, and since then they have been 
monitored and their habitats have been protected by development.
Yes, Humans are assholes for doing horrible things, but we're also taking 
steps to repopulate, protect and educate ourselves about animals and the 
conservation of the environment. The enemy is ignorance and greed. 
Ignorance can lead to a whole lot of trouble.

Golden Tabby Tigers shouldn't be on this list. They are NOT a wild species 
of tiger! They are a designer breed for zoos made purely for profit. As 
like the white tigers, there is no logical reason to breed these tigers for 
conservation since inbreeding is needed to create the coat patterns. A lot 
of offspring end up with deformities like shorten muzzles as a result.﻿

I think the only way we'll ever truly be able to save any of these species 
is to stop expanding our own. With more than 7 billion of us on the planet 
and still counting, we'll have to soon occupy another planet or kill off 
any species that rivals us for more space.

We need to stop having babies - I'm not suggesting we kill anyone, just 
stop making more babies. Sperm banks for people who are infertile or gay 
couples need to be shut down, and we need to encourage adoption instead. 
That's really the only way we'll ever cull our numbers.﻿

responsible for the near extinction of a number on this list is laughable.

coyotes that nearly made it extinct and the 100 or so that were released 
back to the wild aren't hardly producing any offspring as they, yet again, 
are interbreeding with the local coyotes. I know a bit about this due to 
the fact I live in the same county they were released.﻿

'We count down 15 of the rarest, near extinct animals ever to walk the 
earth'

Apart from the 99% percent of life that has existed and is now extinct. I 
think what you should have said is 'We count down 15 of the rarest, near 
extinct animals to *currently* walk the earth'.

Sorry to be a cunt about it, but I can name 15 kinds of animals that are 
allready extinct, meaning they were at one point part of the rarest animals 
on earth, possibly even more so than some of the animals mentioned 
here...apart from the lonely turtle, obviously(poor guy), but more than 
likely at least on par where there is only one of a species.

If you are presenting factual information, then make it factual, at least 
get it right.

Again, sorry to be a cunt, but I do actualy really like you videos and 
lists much more than the douche bags like watchmojo etc because you are 
much more original/interesting with your topics, and to me it's imporatant 
that information is delivered in the correct wording/manner and correct 
context, which is where you got it wrong here. Again, I know I am being 
picky and finding fault in something small, but it's something that's 
imporant when presenting information. Words and knowledge are both 
powerfull so they need to be used right(types the guy with terrible 
spelling and grammar, I know!).

Thanks for all the work you put in. I might be a new subscriber, but I've 
just binged enough to know it's worth subscribing for things that are a 
little more original(probably 'cause your from Oz and have a good sense of 
humour like us Pommy bastards...I bet you are a Red Dwarf fan...and 
Bottom...and The Young Ones).

Keep up the good work!﻿

comments.text:
+Ailin Karina Humanity is a subspecies of Primates. Majority of Primates 
are social creatures and live in groups. Yes, groups are both good and bad 
depending on how you view things and the occurrences of events. Even in 
groups or tribes, Humans ate each other. There are still some isolated 
tribes who still do Cannibalism. Just because we don't do it now doesn't 
mean we won't do it later on. In one scenario, having group is bad since 
they are unable to provide the food and resources needed to survive if they 
were Healthy enough. If you have a Healthy group then well, your able to 
survive. It depends on what happens. And being in a group is not the "Only" 
survival chance, it just means an "Increased"Survival rate. And by 
"Outsiders" do you refer to the Extinct species who did not live in groups? 
Even though those species didn't live in groups, they still managed to 
survive for maybe a few days to a thousand or more years. the conditions 
for them to survive simply changed and the species could not adapt to the 
change and therefore died out.

Humans, on the other hand, have been known to kill *numerous* animals and

comments.text:
I do not defend poachers, and I don't defend those who exploit animals, but 
I do defend sport hunters and I defend a vast majority of the people 
environmentalists choose to strike at.

People say there's no such thing as black and white, that there's gray in 
between.  In reality, a large group of people have forced many to believe 
in only a black and white, and that either the black or white must reign. 
 In the case of many extremist environmentalists the black is the human 
race, and the white is everyone else.  Ere go, the perfect world is where 
every last human is dead and life lives on without us...which is incredibly 
self-destructive and in my opinion a crime against nature's laws itself 
(more on that later).

People rail against hunters for hunting animals for sport.  A lot of people 
don't know (or rather refuse to believe) that these same hunters are the 
reason why we have wildlife reserves and wildlife conservation in the first 
place.  Hunters love their sport, primarily because it is a way of life and 
a means to reconnect with our roots, where we didn't have massive farms 
dedicated to butchering cows for our Mcdonalds hamburgers, and we were 
forced to live off of the lay of the land.  Of course, naturally hunting 
can't happen anymore when you're game is either gone or so rare it will be 
gone soon, so hunters solved this by giving back to nature what they take 
away.  Hunting seasons only occur when the level of prey like Elk or Deer 
is at a considerable level, and even then only certain genders are ever 
targeted each year.  Once you do manage to bag and tag your buck or doe, it 
is considered against the law to waste your meat, so you essentially have 
to carry nearly the entire animal back with you for food, and the antlers 
and head are the sole reminder of your successful hunt.  It's not like in 
the movies where people go about randomly killing rhinos and elephants and 
leaving them to die anymore.  Hunters really do care, and it's only the 
very few (and very disliked and shunned by the greater hunting community) 
stupid ones who are ever caught on camera and added to the hype to get rid 
of them.

Now I know what people are thinking; that this is a long bit of 
conversation written by a guy who probably either lives on a farm or in a 
city and has only the internet to inform him on this.  Nope, I live in 
Idaho, which is almost hunting-controversy central.  We used to have native 
wolves that were hunted down by people who were careless and didn't think 
about the consequences, thinking only about their businesses and the 
well-being of their lifestyle.  Thanks to that purge of a vital predator, 
our entire ecosystem up north has been thrown into chaos, and it's only 
been recently that we've got new wolves back.  But these wolves are not the 
ones we've wanted; these are Canadian wolves with absolutely no experience 
with humans.  They are huge, they see us as food, and they are a problem. 
 Sure, we got our ecosystem back up and running, but it is at the expense 
of much of our wellbeing, and there's a good chance that these wolves will 
meet the same fate as the old Idaho wolf in the future.

By the way; the same people who authorized the killing of those wolves, 
they're among the same people who now sponsor the supposed environmentalist 
groups today, and who also brought in the Canadian Wolves up from the 
north.  They also authorized for vast amounts of salmon to be buried in the 
construction of the dams here in Hell's Canyon when the dams were being 
built.  I know this because my grandfather worked on those dams, and was 
among the people who buried them himself.

Food for thought, people.  The lesson; don't pick an extreme.  Do your 
research and benefit for the good of all, not just for the good of one side 
or the other.  We could all do with a bit of lesson learning in this day 
and age, that I promise you...

comments.text:
Please don't claim that the golden tabby tiger is an endangered species. 
It's a color mutation, no different from a white tiger or abundistic 
('black') tiger. Because it has such a beautiful color, it is - like the 
white tiger - often severly inbred to produce more specimens with the color 
morph. This inbreeding can cause all sorts of weaknesses, including 
crosseyedness, weak joints, weak bones, painful joints, and weak teeth. 
Please don't support any zoo that specifically breeds white/golden 
tabby/albino/abundistic tigers.﻿

comments.text:
So let me get this straight: animal species are wiped out so people can 
enjoy themselves by reproducing too much, having too much food, living in 
comfortable houses, finding cures, collecting resources etc.? Doesn't 
'killing many for the greater good of the few' sound like the morals 
of fictional villains like The Joker, Darth Vader etc.? Heck, Stalin and 
Hitler had the same mentality. But some people try to justify it by saying 
that 'humanity is superior'. I'm sure Hitler would have said the same thing 
about the Nazis, and Stalin would have said the same about himself. 
Literally, we're as bad as Hitler and Stalin, as we kill things just for 
our own enjoyment, as they are 'inferior'. It's so sad how Hitler is made 
out to be such a evil person, when in truth, everyone who's ok with animals 
being slaughtered by the millions just so we can have things like paper and 
wood is just as evil. Hitler was just a normal person, but believed in a 
superior race, instead of a superior species. Only those of us who believe 
animals have as much right to life as us, are not evil and are better than 
Hitler. Because tell me this: what gives us the right to wipe out thousands 
of species, but then when one shark kills 1 person, that shark is made out 
to be evil? The answer is nothing gives us the right. Until you can learn 
to live with animals in harmony, and not see them as a resource for us 
to use, you are evil.﻿

comments.text:
+Zackary Nystrom Indeed that is true, but did they have the decision to 
move to a place *with* active predators to keep them from turning into what 
they turned into?
In other words, I don't think they consciously made the decision to stay.
I think of the key things about anything alive is staying where it feels 
comfortable, and to stay as far away from danger if possible.
Yes, perhaps they chose to stay.
However only because there was no danger.
For example, say you lived in a neighborhood where every day was a fight 
for your life.
You walk outside, you risk your life.
You take a drink of water, you risk your life.
You try to rape Carl, you risk your life.
Now, say...if you found your perfect utopia, an ideal place built from 
*your* own fantasies, with no strings attached, would you leave it? Or go 
back to the neighborhood that harbored all the dangers?
comments.author: Marcus Redfield

comments.text:
Just going to make as many points as possible. The government has something 
to do with it but not a lot. Basic society causes the most problems, 
construction, industry, hunting, etc. But the "Government" are also doing 
things to help the situation when possible. Natural Selection is when 
animals are born with a mutation that suites the environment they live in, 
giving them a higher chance to survive, which means a higher chance to 
reproduce and pass that mutation on to the rest of the species. It has 
nothing to do with people arming themselves. When you pick up a firearm, 
you can't say you mutated. Obesity is just another disadvantage of basic 
society. Humans aren't meant to be like everyday animals, we as a species 
can't be natural and still survive. We need clothes, weapons, tools, 
inventions, communication, cooked food, medicine, and the list goes on. We 
don't really count anymore when it comes to a food chain. Naturally 
extinction isn't a problem unless the species isn't adapted to survive. 
Although population increase and decrease is possible, we just normally get 
in the way of the natural pattern on accident. Ecosystems evolve together 
so that everything in it works together. We aren't part of a ecosystem, we 
are alien invaders. We didn't grown in a specific area, allowing us to 
connect to a food chain in an area of the world.
comments.author: Zackary “Zraxid” N.

comments.text:
+Marcus Woolley We humans are at the top of the food chain. It's as black 
and white as that. I know it's hard to accept, but if you don't like it, do 
something about it. Maybe perhaps one day, you can eliminate them.
However that displaces the natural balance of society if you were to get 
rid of a number of doctors or scientists, or other people that are sadly 
essential to the natural flow of Earth.
Times demand different things with our advancements. 
(Just a thought, I still would prefer to keep things like the Orange tabby 
tiger alive ;~;)

comments.text:
+BlowingCreepers Humans aren't the only animals able to "talk". Every 
animal has the ability to form some type of vocal language, to which other 
animals of that species can understand. Same thing with early 
neanderthal's, they might not have used the words the same as we do today, 
but they could have easily "grunted" or some other type of vocal movement 
to express what they wanted to say. I don't think it'll come to the point 
of primates being able to speak like we do (naturally anyway), but they do 
understand physical motion or "hand gestures" to understand us ( and vice 
versa). If you ask me, that's pretty fucking awesome as is considering how 
far both species have come in just a couple millenium.

Uhhhh the strawberry tiger and white lion ( and white tiger, which is 
basically an albino Bengal tiger) themselves are not endangered, because 
they are not  a separate species. They are simply genetic mutations (rare 
yes), of species that  already exist. Thus the reason they are" endangered" 
, because most conservationists will not spend the resources and effort to 
protect  a rare recessive genetic mutation of an already existing animal.﻿

comments.text:
The so called 'Strawberry Tigers' are not a separate species. And not 
endangered, along with what we call 'white tigers' they are a colour morph 
of normal tigers. They are very unlikely to be found in the wild, due to 
the fact that they are inbred within captivity to create the vivid colours. 
Which also unfortunately can make them hugely disfigured and have a short 
lifespan. Just look it up. ﻿
